feed.title: Almost Vacant: James A. Woods and Nicolas Wright Turn on the Pilot Light
feed.subtitle: The characters they play on their trial comedy episode may appear almost vacant in matters cerebral, but Montreal actors James A. Woods and Nicolas Wright would seem to possess just the right savvy and stuff for showbiz success.

entry.title: Almost Vacant: James A. Woods and Nicolas Wright Turn on the Pilot Light
entry.summary: James A. Woods and Nicolas Wright attract Comedy Central’s attention with Almost Vacant

link.Abstract: The characters they play on their trial comedy episode may appear almost vacant in matters cerebral, but Montreal actors James A. Woods and Nicolas Wright would seem to possess just the right savvy and stuff for showbiz success.

content.div:
MONTREAL - The characters they play on their trial comedy episode may appear almost vacant in matters cerebral, but Montreal actors James A. Woods and Nicolas Wright would seem to possess just the right savvy and stuff for showbiz success.

Comedy Central, the most respected pay/cable outlet devoted to humour in the U.S. and pretty much everywhere else on the planet, has just given the tandem an order to develop a pilot for their own TV series, based on that 30-minute trial presentation called Almost Vacant.

Woods and Wright play bumbling buddies working their way to the bottom at a low-end hotel in Albany, N.Y. in Almost Vacant. And if you think these guys are slackers, wait until you meet their even more inept co-workers and friends.

There are some truly inspired hysterical moments, thanks in large part to the comic timing and performances of the two principals. But it is their writing that could be their ticket to the comedy bigs here.

Woods and Wright, who have been writing partners for nearly a decade, penned the Almost Vacant script and will be enhancing the story for the Comedy Central pilot. They will also serve as exec producers, with their buddy Matthew Shewchuk producing.

“When we first wrote this episode, we said to ourselves that it was actually shootable – which is not always the case,” says Wright, 29. “There are a lot of people shooting pilot presentations in which they can only do two or three scenes. But because ours was pretty low-budget production-wise, we thought we could shoot the whole thing.”

The pair approached Shewchuk, who was captivated by their script. The three then ponied up $30,000 and were hoping they would get by with a little help from their actor cronies.

“We were very lucky,” acknowledges Woods, 32. “We called on all the favours we could ever call on from our friends. Amazingly, they all said yes. They flew in to Montreal on all the frequent-flyer points they could muster, from L.A., Vancouver and Toronto. If not for them, the shoot would have easily cost us 10 times more.”

But their actor friends will be getting payback. The same characters will be employed in the Comedy Central pilot, which is slated to start shooting at the end of March in Montreal – which will once again double for Albany. (Woods and Wright rightly figured that a pilot for a U.S. pay/cable channel should be based in an American location.) Woods and Wright also lucked out on the Comedy Central deal. Comedy Central executive Seth Cohen was the first person Wright’s agent approached with the finished presentation.

“Just a few weeks after he received it, he called back and said he wanted to order a pilot and underwrite the entire cost,” Wright relays. “We were totally blown away. And Comedy Central has been so supportive since.”

But credit also goes to the guys. Their instincts were correct.

“When we were writing and then shooting, we knew right away it didn’t have a mainstream network feel, that it was more geared to cable programming,” Woods says. “So we made it more loose and took more liberties. But, seriously, it’s a dream come true to have the first cable channel we approached give us the go-ahead. It was surreal.”

“We will be writing a new script for the pilot, but what is so encouraging is that they really don’t want to change much in the way of the tone,” Wright adds. “They like the characters and the chemistry between the actors, and they want to see where we can take them all in the pilot.”

They hope to deliver the finished pilot to Comedy Central in May, and they expect to get a response from the network by the end of the summer as to whether a series of 10 to 13 episodes will be ordered.

“It could all come to an end or could be a new beginning,” Woods says. “There are so many variables in TV. So we’ll just take it one day at a time and try to make the pilot as funny as it can be.”

Woods and Wright first hooked up when they co-starred in the award-winning 2003 Canadian indie flick Hatley High, directed by Phil Price. The latter also directed the duo in the 2006 comedy series The Business, which netted a Gemini nomination for best ensemble cast.

For his part, Wright received the award for most promising newcomer at the film-festival component of Just for Laughs in 2004 for his short Toutouffe. He also co-starred on the 2009-10 CBS sitcom Accidentally on Purpose.

“But we have pretty much spent the last 10 years together pounding on our keyboards,” Wright says.

Woods is no relation to the actor James Woods, but is the son of prominent Montreal lawyer James Woods.

“Now he’s happy,” Woods says of his father. “But let’s just say that when I quit school at 19 to pursue this career, it wasn’t quite as celebrated an event.”

As is so often the case, however, Canadian performers have to go to the U.S. to get recognized on their home turf.

“It’s a real Catch-22,” Woods says. “To make it in Canada, you have to head to the States. But to be able to get to the States, you have had to do something in Canada to get those cracks in the door open just a little.”

While the guys have had their share of odd jobs over the years, they never worked in a hotel.

“Instead of doing something high concept, we decided to write a show about us in the most simple and funny of terms,” Wright says. “So we figured making ourselves goofballs in a hotel setting wasn’t much of a stretch.”

“We’re basically bumbling idiots with semi-high IQs,” Woods blurts.

“With the emphasis on ‘semi,’ ” retorts Wright.

Regardless, many a bumbler with a semi-high IQ has gone on to score in the world of comedy. Often, it’s actually a prerequisite.

bbrownstein@montrealgazette.com

twitter.com/billbrownstein

entry.title: South Park Renewed For Three More Seasons

link.Abstract: The foul-mouthed animated satire has been renewed until 2016, taking it through its 20th season.

link.Abstract: Matt Stone (L) and Trey Parker (R) will stay on to write, produce and voice the beloved inhabitants of South Park, Colorado through a 20th season.
